report_title: Apparel Knitting Mills in the US
executive_summary: The Apparel Knitting Mills industry has faced headwinds owing to operational inefficiencies and heightened competition from overseas manufacturers. This has contributed to decreased production levels and a contraction in market share. Despite these pressures, some companies within the industry have managed to innovate and adapt, leveraging advancements in textile technologies and niche markets to sustain their operations. Industry revenue has decreased at a CAGR of 3.9% over the past five years and is expected to total $1.1 billion in 2024, when revenue will drop by an estimated 0.5%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Apparel knitting mills are confronting challenges because of increased import penetration
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Countries like China, India and Bangladesh have substantially lower labor costs than the US. According to the American Apparel and Footwear Association, China's average manufacturing wage is significantly less than in the US, redirecting business from US Apparel Knitting Mills. Also, these countries' strong manufacturing infrastructure and supply chains enhance their appeal.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Spiking input costs and regulatory expenses challenge manufacturers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Prices for key inputs like cotton and synthetic fibers have spiked significantly because of supply chain disruptions and increased global demand. For instance, cotton prices experienced a notable climb in recent years, pressuring mills to either absorb the costs or pass them onto consumers, usually leading to lower overall consumption.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: E-commerce growth drives manufacturers to embrace the DTC model for enhanced profitability
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The exponential growth of e-commerce has prompted numerous apparel knitting mills to transition towards online sales channels, strategically adopting the direct-to-consumer (DTC) model to better reach customers and streamline their distribution processes.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Manufacturers will enjoy favorable trade conditions
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Domestic manufacturers will benefit from reduced competition as trade barriers, such as tariffs on goods imported from countries like China, become more prevalent. These tariffs climb the cost of foreign goods, making US-made products more attractive to US consumers looking for more affordable options.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Innovations and research will elevate apparel knitting mills to new heights of performance
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Innovations in knitting techniques will enable apparel knitting mills to produce more complex and high-performance garments. This includes everything from seamless athletic wear to antimicrobial fabrics. US-based mills like Shima Seiki USA are already investing in advanced knitting machines to stay competitive and meet evolving market needs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Apparel knitting mills embracing sustainability will flourish
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As environmental awareness grows, more consumers, especially Millennials and Gen Z, will prioritize sustainability when purchasing clothing. Brands that commit to eco-friendly practices and transparency will likely see loyal followings expand.

industry_definition: Manufacturers in this industry produce knitting apparel and fabric before creating finished garments. The industry also encompasses part-time entrepreneurs who craft knitting apparel and accessories.

Rising pressures from retailers and wholesalers have forced manufacturers to reduce prices to remain competitive.
Imports are the primary source of external competition. Domestic apparel knitting mills face severe price-based competition from low-cost manufacturers in Asia and South America.

Import penetration from low-cost countries challenges apparel knitting mills. These mills are adopting advanced technologies and e-commerce strategies, including the direct-to-consumer model, to stay competitive and reduce costs.

The push for "Made in US" products will be pivotal. Local knitting mills will benefit significantly as retailers and consumers prioritize locally sourced goods, spurring innovation in knitting techniques and a shift toward sustainable materials.
Three companies hold over 5.0% of the market. Hanes, Renfro Corporation and Golden Lady Company leverage their significant scale to produce in bulk and reduce costs efficiently.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulates the Apparel Knitting Mills industry by enforcing air and water quality standards, managing hazardous waste and ensuring compliance with the Clean Air Act and Clean Water Act. The agency issues permits, monitors emissions and conducts inspections to minimize environmental impact and promote sustainable practices within the industry.

OSHA regulates the Apparel Knitting Mills industry through standards that ensure safe working conditions, including machine guarding, proper ergonomics and exposure limits to hazardous substances. Employers must maintain clean facilities, provide safety training and implement emergency procedures. Regular inspections and record-keeping are mandated to.

The Fair Packaging and Labeling Act (FPLA) requires apparel knitting mills to provide accurate labels on their products, including the product's identity, the manufacturer's or distributor's name and address and the net quantity of contents. This ensures transparency and helps consumers make informed purchasing decisions while maintaining industry standards and preventing deceptive practices.

The US Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) provides patent protection for innovative knitting technologies and design patents for unique apparel designs. Also, it grants trademarks to protect brand names and logos in the apparel industry, helping companies safeguard their intellectual property and maintain a competitive edge in the market.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Skilled Labor is Needed for Quality Production
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Skilled labor is imperative for upholding production quality in apparel knitting mills. The expertise of seasoned employees is vital for manufacturing high-quality products and the precise and efficient operation of specialized machinery. This necessity underscores the justification for offering higher wages to attract and retain such talent.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Shift in Fashion Trends Adds to Revenue Volatility in Apparel Knitting Mills
volatility_points.volatility_description: Rapid swings in consumer preferences can make production runs unprofitable if the desired styles change unexpectedly, leading to surpluses.

Revenue volatility spikes when competing imports surge. Foreign goods often come in waves, driven by lower costs or new trade deals, making it tough for domestic mills to predict stable income. Retail giants increasingly turn to foreign manufacturers for budget-friendly bulk items. This trend destabilizes domestic mills' revenue, forcing them to slash prices or lose market share to cheaper imports.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many knitting mills are now using organic cotton, recycled polyester, and other sustainable materials. These eco-friendly fabrics reduce the environmental impact and cater to the growing consumer demand for sustainable products.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Advancements in Knitting Technology Revolutionize On-Demand Custom Manufacturing for Tailored Consumer Needs
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Advancements in knitting technology now allow for precise on-demand manufacturing. This enables customers to order custom sizes, styles and personalized designs, reducing inventory waste and meeting specific consumer needs.

FAQs.question: Have your company's sales been heavily affected by the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: A strong US economy certainly helps aid revenue, but other factors, like import penetration and input prices, impact revenue. Renewed international trade threatens industry performance via enhanced import competition, but increased exports provide new streams of revenue.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche, or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: A diverse portfolio of products allows companies to adapt to fashion trends.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage volatile input prices?
FAQs.answer: Input costs for this industry vary widely yearly and cannot always be passed downstream. The world price of cotton has been surging.

FAQs.question: Have any trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The National Council of Textile Organizations (NCTO) supports apparel knitting mills by advocating for favorable trade policies, providing industry insights and promoting domestic manufacturing. They work to ensure fair competition, lobby for import tariffs and advance technological innovation. By representing industry interests, NCTO aims to boost the competitiveness and sustainability of textile and apparel production.

FAQs.question: Has your company purchased any new equipment recently?
FAQs.answer: Expenditure on wages in this industry accounts for a much larger portion of revenue than expenditure on capital. However, innovation is necessary to compete with dominant imports.

FAQs.question: How has your company's growth compared to your main competitors during the period?
FAQs.answer: Like most clothing industries, companies compete based largely on price. Marketing products as higher-quality and longer-lasting has allowed some companies to better compete with dominant imports.

FAQs.question: How has your ability to pass on cost increases to consumers been affected by the global pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Average profit has recently suffered from supply chain interruptions and a lack of consumer confidence, limiting the ability to pass on costs. Like most clothing industries, companies compete based largely on price and diminishing consumer sentiment has spurred many losses as companies compete for this reduced demand.

FAQs.question: How can you boost brand awareness? Have you employed effective social media tactics?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers that produce upscale products need an established brand name and a strong reputation to justify prices. Brand-name companies have been more successful than smaller-name producers, as they need to spend less on marketing to capture limited consumer demand.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue is derived from department stores?
FAQs.answer: Department and discount department stores are a sizeable downstream market for apparel knitting mills. An increase in demand for apparel and accessories at the retail level translates into demand growth for manufacturers via a hike in order numbers. Demand from department stores is expected to decrease in 2023, posing a potential threat to the industry. Department and discount department stores are the leading retailers of apparel and accessories in the US. Online sales continue to surge in popularity among consumers.

FAQs.question: Which of your products has been the most resilient to fluctuations in demand? Do you offer any discount products?
FAQs.answer: Increases in the level of per capita disposable income can boost demand for consumer goods supplied by this industry. Basic cotton socks consistently have resilient demand because of their versatility and universal usage in apparel knitting mills.

FAQs.question: How has your company competed with lower-priced goods as a result of import penetration?
FAQs.answer: Growth in the volume of imported apparel and accessories in the US has intensified the competitive pressures experienced by domestic manufacturers. Some companies market their products as higher-end and longer-lasting to avoid being undercut by cheaper imports.
